channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Germany Bans Support of ISIS
item.description: Anyone caught displaying the black flag of the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, whether in public or over the Internet, will face charges.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Oscar Pistorius Guilty of Culpable Homicide in Killing of Girlfriend
item.description: Oscar Pistorius was found guilty of negligent killing in the shooting of Reeva Steenkamp, but he was granted bail and will remain free until sentencing procedures on Oct. 13.
item.dc:creator: By SARAH LYALL and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Oscar Pistorius listening to the verdict at his trial in Pretoria, South Africa, on Friday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Thieves Follow the Money to Corrupt Officials’ Homes
item.description: Corrupt officials make ideal targets: They are known to keep large supplies of cash in their residences and are reluctant to report thefts for fear of a graft investigation.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Corrupt officials are thought to keep much of their ill-gotten gains in cash to avoid bank accounts that might attract the attention of investigators.

item.title: Cuba to Send Expanded Medical Team to Fight Ebola
item.description: The commitment of personnel to the health crisis is the biggest from any country, but it remains insufficient, the top United Nations health official warned.
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: European Union Details Tightened Sanctions Against Russia
item.description: The measures, aimed at Russia’s financial, energy and defense sectors, could be revised swiftly if a cease-fire in Ukraine holds, Western officials said.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER and NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Letter From Europe: NATO’s Hopes for Russia Have Turned to Dismay
item.description: In a declaration at a summit 24 years ago, NATO expressed elation at the thought of a democratic future for Eastern Europe, but Putin has put an end to those expectations.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Australia Raises Terrorism Alert Level to High
item.description: Prime Minister Tony Abbott said Friday that there was “a body of evidence that points to the increased likelihood of a terrorist attack in Australia.”
item.dc:creator: By MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: Chinese Dissident’s Trial Is Cut Short After Lawyers Refuse to Attend
item.description: An attorney for the dissident, best known by his pen name, Guo Feixiong, said that “whatever a lawyer said in the courtroom would have no effect.”
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Expands Investment in Tanzania
item.description: China is providing $412.5 million to build a logistics hub in the Tanzanian port of Dar es Salaam.
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China with President Jakaya Kikwete of Tanzania in Dar es Salaam last year. During his Africa tour, Mr. Xi tried to address concerns that China was only interested in Africa’s natural resources.

item.title: Oscar Pistorius Returns to Court as Judge Ponders Charges
item.description: Judge Thokozile Matilda Masipa is ruling on lesser charges after finding he did not commit premeditated murder.
item.dc:creator: By SARAH LYALL and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Oscar Pistorius arriving at the courthouse in Pretoria, South Africa, on Friday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: In China, a Search for Oscar Contenders
item.description: “Gone with the Bullets,” “Coming Home” and “Wolf Totem” are attracting notice as possible Academy Award entrants. A film from mainland China has yet to win an Oscar, and officials are eager for the cultural validation that the award would bring.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Jiang Wen at a news conference in Beijing for his film "Gone with the Bullets."

item.title: Retired Gen. John R. Allen in Line to Lead Effort vs. ISIS
item.description: Mr. Allen, who was the top American commander in Afghanistan, will coordinate the international coalition to fight the militant Islamist group, an official said.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Japanese Newspaper Retracts Fukushima Disaster Report and Fires Editor
item.description: The move comes a month after The Asahi Shimbun retracted articles on another hot-button issue about Japan’s wartime legacy: women forced to serve in brothels.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: The Asahi Shimbun was distributed on a Tokyo street last year.

item.title: Arabs Give Tepid Support to U.S. Fight Against ISIS
item.description: Three years after the United States left Iraq, its return to the region is getting a less than enthusiastic welcome, with allies finding ways to avoid specific commitments to an expanded effort against Sunni extremists.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD and DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry in Saudi Arabia, where he spoke to officials from across the region.

item.title: Try as He May, John McCain Can’t Shake Falsehoods About Ties to ISIS
item.description: The Arizona Republican has been hounded after a picture of him with members of the Free Syrian Army was misinterpreted and doctored purposely to make it appear that he supported ISIS, which he does not.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: Senator John McCain in a picture on the blog Socio-Economic History, with people in or aligned with the Free Syrian Army.

item.title: U.S. Pins Hope on Syrian Rebels With Loyalties All Over the Map
item.description: President Obama’s determination to train moderate rebels in the battle against ISIS leaves the U.S. dependent on a diverse group riven by infighting.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD, ERIC SCHMITT and MARK MAZZETTI

item.title: With Eye on Scotland, Catalonia Hails Its Secession Bid
item.description: Artur Mas, the president of the regional government, is fighting opposition from Spain’s central government as the Nov. 9 vote approaches.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:description: Hundreds of thousands of people crowded into central Barcelona on Thursday at a rally on Catalonia’s National Day.

item.title: On a Day Devoted to Past Events, Focus on New Terror Link
item.description: As President Obama honored the victims of Sept. 11, 2001, the White House argued that he had the right to wage his new ISIS fight under the same legal authority he used for Al Qaeda.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: President Obama and his wife, Michelle, on Thursday at a ceremony on the South Lawn of the White House marking the anniversary of the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks.

item.title: Oscar Pistorius Not Guilty of Murder; Still Faces Lesser Homicide Charge
item.description: Judge Thokozile Matilda Masipa is expected to rule on Friday on the remaining charge of “culpable homicide” in the killing of Reeva Steenkamp.
item.dc:creator: By SARAH LYALL

item.title: Islamabad Journal: Beleaguered Pakistani Capital Inches Back to Normal
item.description: Islamabad, which has been disrupted by vast traffic jams, barricaded streets and teeming political rallies, is slowly beginning to inch back to its usual routines.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD and ZIA ur-REHMAN
item.media:description: Muhammad Tahir-ul Qadri, left at railing, a preacher leading protests in Islamabad, waved to supporters at a sit-in last week.

item.title: Deal Reached on Gaza Reconstruction, Palestinian Leader Says
item.description: President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority said Thursday night that he had reached an agreement with Israel and the United Nations to import reconstruction materials to the Gaza Strip.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: China Fines Volkswagen and Chrysler for Antitrust Violations
item.description: Regulators imposed penalties totaling $46 million, saying the automakers conspired to keep prices high on cars and replacement parts.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER and CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: A production line of Golf sedans manufactured at a Volkswagen plant jointly operated with China FAW in Guangdong Province.

item.title: U.S. and Europe Back New Economic Sanctions Against Russia
item.description: The measures, which will take effect on Friday, are meant to punish the country for its role in promoting separatist warfare in eastern Ukraine, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER and DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: A line to buy bread at a bakery in Luhansk, Ukraine. Russia is being punished for promoting a separatist war in eastern Ukraine.

item.title: With Gas Cut Off, Ukraine Looks West
item.description: Ukraine, which receives more than half of its supply from Russia, is looking to reduce its need amid a price dispute and military action with Russian separatists.
item.dc:creator: By DANNY HAKIM
item.media:credit: Piotr Malecki for The New York Times
item.media:description: A compressor station operated by the Eustream company at Velke Kapusany, Slovakia. A reversal of the usual pipeline flow has sent gas from Slovakia to Ukraine.

item.title: Spate of Suicides by Chinese Officials Tied to Drive Against Graft
item.description: Some researchers suspect the suicides may be linked to an anticorruption campaign begun last year by President Xi Jinping, the toughest in decades.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:credit: Didi Kirsten Tatlow/The New York Times
item.media:description: Graffiti referring to the suicide of Li Haihua. It reads, in part, "The prosecutor's office and city government are in cahoots."
